name: Chicken Lombardy
recipeIngredient: 6 (4 ounce) skinless, boneless chicken breast halves

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C).
Lay bacon strips side by side and slightly overlapping on a baking sheet. Rub brown sugar on bacon until all brown sugar is gone.
Bake in the preheated oven until bacon is done, about 30 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool.
Increase the oven temperature to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking dish.
Melt 2 tablespoon butter in a skillet over medium-high heat. Add mushrooms and cook, stirring constantly, until just tender, 3 to 5 minutes. Remove from the heat.

Cut each chicken breast in half lengthwise. Place between 2 sheets of heavy-duty plastic wrap and flatten with a meat mallet or rolling pin to a thickness of 1/8 inch. Place flour in a shallow plate and dredge chicken.

Melt 2 tablespoons butter in a large, nonstick skillet over medium heat. Working in batches, cook chicken until golden, 3 to 4 minutes per side. Transfer to the prepared baking dish and cook remaining chicken, adding more butter as needed. Reserve pan drippings in the skillet.
Add chicken broth to the pan drippings and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered and stirring occasionally, for 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Pour sauce over the chicken.
Chop bacon and combine with mozzarella cheese, Parmesan cheese, and green onions. Sprinkle over the chicken.
Bake, uncovered, in the preheated oven until cheese melts, 12 to 14 minutes.

review.reviewBody: 3.22.21 I try not to stray too far from a new recipe, but to me, this had “overcooked” written all over it.  Recipe tells you to pound out the chicken to 1/8 inch (that’s thin), cook in a skillet 3-4 minutes per side, and a little later, it heads into a 450ºF oven for 12-14 minutes.  IMO that will turn the chicken into a cinder.  So here’s what I did.  I browned the chicken in a skillet until it was golden, and  at 1/8 inch, it then was cooked!   If you add the chicken broth to the skillet, and simmer for 10 minutes, you’ll literally have no “sauce” per se.  I think it wouldn’t hurt to add more chicken broth, simmer intensifying the flavor, and that will also enhance the moistness of the chicken. Why cook “cooked” chicken in the oven at 450º for 12-24 minutes just to melt the cheese?  I skipped the cooking in the oven and put it under the broiler for several minutes to melt the cheese.  In the future, I’ll pound out my chicken to 1/4 inch because I thought 1/8 was just too thin, I’ll add more chicken broth, probably just a little thyme, and cook as described above.  This was very tasty, it’s pretty simple, and just needs a little tweaking.  Don’t want to discourage others from totally following the recipe, just wanted to explain what worked for me.  This chicken is good and worth your effo
